{{Quote|My mother wishes me to let Lord Eddard join the Night's Watch... stripped of all titles and powers he would serve the realm in permanent exile. And my Lady Sansa has begged mercy for her father. But they have the soft hearts of women... so long as I'm your King treason shall never go unpunished! Ser Ilyn, bring me his head!|King Joffrey sentences Lord Eddard to die.|Baelor}}
The '''Execution of Eddard Stark''' is a pivotal event in the nascent [[War of the Five Kings|conflict]] caused by the death of [[Robert Baratheon]], paving the way for its transformation into a full-fledged civil war.
sections.In the books:
In the ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' novels, the execution occurs in an almost identical fashion to the TV series. There are only small differences, such as the fact that [[High Septon (Before the riot of King's Landing)|High Septon]] is the one who speaks of the justice and mercy of the gods, and he and [[Varys]] protest Joffrey's decision to execute Ned. The book also gives no indication that Ned spotted Arya in the crowd or instructed Yoren to protect her; Yoren seems to find her by chance.

Ser [[Barristan Selmy]] is present at the execution in the guise of Arstan Whitebeard, though this is not revealed until ''A Dance With Dragons'', after he has joined the service of Daenerys Targaryen. He tells her that Eddard was against the murder of her family and the assassination attempt on her and her son, but she still considers him equally responsible and labels him as one of the "Usurper's dogs".
